bestBHT.bht: Through the teachings of the Holy Spirit and the dealings of Providence, I have learned to be content in every state. This contentment is not based on self-sufficiency, but on recognizing that my sufficiency comes from God. Christianity elevates the concept of self-sufficiency from the prideful independence of the Stoics to the contentment of the Christian, whose sufficiency is found in God. It is a contentment that is not based on the absence of want, but on gratitude and thankfulness for everything, whether little or more.

Henry Alford: My meaning is not, that...in respect of, i.e. according to, i.e. in consequence of.
For I learned...in the state in which I am...to find competence.

Self-sufficing will express its meaning of independence of external help, but is liable to be misunderstood: 'competent' is not in use in this sense, though the abstract noun competence is: the German genülam gives it well.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I, for my part, have learned, by the teaching of the Holy Spirit, and the dealings of Providence, to be content in every state.

The Greek, literally expresses 'independent of others, and having sufficiency in one's self.' But Christianity has raised the term above the haughty self-sufficiency of the heathen Stoic to the contentment of the Christian, whose sufficiency is not in self, but in God.
But Christianity has raised the term above the haughty self-sufficiency of the heathen Stoic to the contentment of the Christian, whose sufficiency is not in self, but in God.
Albert Barnes: I have learned, in whatsoever state I am, therewith to be content - That is, to have a contented mind.
A contented mind is an invaluable blessing, and is one of the fruits of religion in the soul.
One of the secrets of happiness is to have a mind satisfied with all the allotments of Providence.
Marvin Vincent: Content [αυταρκης] . Lit., self - sufficient. Only here in the New Testament.
Paul is self - sufficient through the power of the new self: not he, but Christ in him.
The kindred noun aujtarkeia sufficiency, occurs 2 Corinthians 9:8; 1 Timothy 6:6.
John Calvin: For it was of importance that his constancy and moderation should be known by the Philippians, to whom he was a pattern of life.
That man can never be poor in mind, who is satisfied with the lot which has been assigned to him by God.
Want refers here to disposition, for that man can never be poor in mind, who is satisfied with the lot which has been assigned to him by God.
Philip Schaff: Not that I speak in respect of want. This is not my cause of joy, that what was lacking unto me has been supplied by your bounty. It is not that I have felt want, and have been relieved from it.
I have learned, I know, I have found the secret, as though he would mark something progressive in his description of what his life as a Christian preacher has taught him.
He had all with him that he needed in having Christ, and of this sustaining presence the apostle was often assured.
Archibald T. Robertson: In respect of want (καθ' υστερησιν). Late and rare word from υστερεω, to be behind or too late, only here and Mark 12:44 in N.T.
I have learned (εμαθον). Simply, "I did learn" (constative second aorist active indicative of μανθανω, to learn, looking at his long experience as a unit.
Paul is contented with his lot and he learned that lesson long ago. Socrates said as to who is wealthiest: 'He that is content with least, for αυταρκεια is nature's wealth.'
John Gill: Though he had nothing, he possessed all things, and was as happy, and in as comfortable a frame, and in as much content then as now.
Such persons have a sort of an all-sufficiency in them; they are thankful for everything they have, be it little or more, and in every state, whether of adversity or prosperity.

It was not what he had acquired by his industry, but what he had 'learned'; and that not in the school of nature and reason, while an unregenerate man; nor at the feet of Gamaliel, while he was training up under him in the law of Moses, and in the traditions of the elders; but he learned it of God, and was taught it by the revelation of Christ, and under the teachings of the Spirit of God.
John Wesley: I have learned — From God. He only can teach this.
In everything, therewith to be content — Joyfully and thankfully patient. Nothing less is Christian content.
We may observe a beautiful gradation in the expressions, I have learned; I know; I am instructed; I can.

bhtAttempts.bht: I have learned, through the teaching of the Holy Spirit and the circumstances appointed by God, to be content in every situation. This contentment does not stem from self-sufficiency or independence, but rather from a recognition that my sufficiency comes from God. In having Christ, I possess all that I need, and through His sustaining presence, I am able to find competence in all things. This contentment is not based on the absence of want, but rather on a disposition of gratitude and thankfulness for everything that I have, whether it be little or more. It is a joyful and patient contentment that is a result of the Christian faith.

Through the teachings of the Holy Spirit and the dealings of Providence, I have learned to be content in every state. This contentment is not based on self-sufficiency, but on recognizing that my sufficiency comes from God. Christianity elevates the concept of self-sufficiency from the prideful independence of the Stoics to the contentment of the Christian, whose sufficiency is found in God. It is a contentment that is not based on the absence of want, but on gratitude and thankfulness for everything, whether little or more.
